div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The early morning was very misty but the air began to clear about eight o'clock. The humidity is excessive. The barometer remains steady.

div.head: Death.
div.p: OREL.- On the 13th inst., at Maison Ozel, Bacos, Anton Orel, aged 70 years. Friends will please accept this intima- tion. No flowers.
The Egyptian Gazette
An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Saturday, October 14, 1905.

div.head: The Post Office.
div.p: We understand that the request recently published by the Post Office Administration, asking the public to put on their correspon- dence the name of the street, or failing that the name of the quarter of the resident recipients of letters, has met with little or no attention. The administration will soon be compelled to discontinue the practice of send- ing letters addressed to A. Cairo or B. Alex- andria to the addresses, and though their action is likely to meet with considerable criticism from those members of the Egyptian Public who regard one of the most useful and necessary State departments in the same fashion as an exacting mistress regards an overworked housemaid, a short historical account of the methods employed by the Post Office should prove that hostile criticism is, in this case, misplaced and undeserved by the very energetic and efficient administration against which it may be aimed.

Previous to 1890 a few people used to re- gister their addresses at the local Post Offices and pay a charge of P.T. 5, so that their letters might be forwarded to them. In 1890 the charge was abolished and the public were invited to register their names and addres- ses free of charge. This they did in steadily increasing numbers. Owing to the streets being unnamed, no other address byt Alex- andria or Cairo etc., could be put on cor- respondence. The numbers registered increased and it became necessary to ask the public to give the name of the street where the addresses lived or, failing the street, the quarter. In Alexandria the numbers registered is now 39,000 odd, of whom 22,700 are Europeans. In Cairo there are half as many again and while there are a few employes of the Department who have grown up with the service and know where most people live , the younger generation cannot be ex- pected to acquire this knowledge. After all the Administration is only asking the public to do what is done in every civilised country. Indeed letters addressed to Smith, London or Dubois, Paris, are usually sent back at once to the office of origin.

BERLIN, October 13. It is understood here that Great Britain has informally assured Germany of the baselessness of the report published by the "Matin," but the tone of the semi official press indicates that Germany is not satisfied, and wishes an official repudiation. This, however, is generally regarded in England and in France as being Unreasonable. (Reuter)

LONDON, October 13. The Government does not intend to make a statement regarding the revelations of the "Matin," but Reuter's Agency is enabled to state authoritatively that the Government has informed Germany that France never asked nor did Great Britain offer any assistance, as the question never arose. (Reuter)
STOCKHOLM, October 13. The Swedish Riksdag has approved the convention of dissolution. (Reuter)
STOCKHOLM. October 13. The Riksdag has approved the Karlstad agreement. (Havas)
TOKIO, Ootober 13. Admiral Noel and staff have been received by the Mikado. (Reuter)
TOKIO, October 13. Admiral Noel has lunched with the Empe- ror. Cordial toasts were exchanged. (Reuter)

ST. PETERSBURG, October 13. The Chief of Police at Krasnoyarsk was killed while returning from the theatre yester¬day evening. The Sub-Chief of Police at Kisbi- neff has also been assassinated. He was largely responsible for the massacres of 1903, and the recent anti-Jewish disturbances. (Reuter)
Moscow, October 13. The strikers in Moscow having erected barri-cades to-day, the Cossacks charged and broke them down. There are sevoral injured. (R.)

ST. PETERSBURG, October 13. Prince. Trobetrkni, the leader of the mo¬derate reformers, died suddenly at the close of a spirited speech before a special Government Commission regarding the troubles at Moscow University. (Reuter)
Moscow, October 13. Prince Trubetzkoi, rector of the University, has died suddenly. (Havas)
PARIS, October 13. A note from the Havas Agency declares that the Japanese rumours concerning the retir¬ement of M. Declasse are not correct. (H.)
WASHINGTON, October 13. Ratifications of the Russo-Japanese treaty will be exchanged here to-morrow. (Reuter)
LONDON, October 13., Lord Cromer has left for Egypt. (Reuter)
LONDON, October 13. Sir Henry Irving died suddenly of syncope at Bradford after having performed in the theatre. (Reuter)

STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Boulac district of Cairo during to-morrow night and at dawn of the 16th inst. will be poisoned by the police. Those found in the Gamalieh district on Monday night and at dawn of the 17th inst. will be dealt with in the same way.

COAL IMPORTS.—During the period from the 1st of January to the 12tb of October 842.530 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 457,203, Newcastle 194,487. Scotland 98,112, Yorkshire 61,225, and other places 31,503 tons. In the same period of last year 814,430 tons were received.

THE AHIAMHIU THEATRE. — The Della Guardia Dramatic Company will represent II Suicidio at the Alhambra Theatre to-night and for the unusual weekly matinee at 4 15 p.m. to-morrow LA Famiglia Pont Biquet is billed and at the evening performance Madame Sans- Gehe will be staged. From to-morrow the prices at this theatre are reduced as follows:— Boxes P.T. 60, Front Seats P.T. 10.

PRO CALABRIA. — The Cairo Musical and Dramatic Society have arranged for a grand concert to be given at the Khedivial Opera House on Thursday, the 26th October, com-mencing at 9 p.m., in aid of the victims of the recent earthquake in Calabria. The concert will be under the distinguished patronage of H.H. the Khedive, the Earl of Cromer, the Diplomatic Agents of Italy, America and Spain, General Bullock, C.B.. and H.E. the Sirdar. By kind permission of Lient. Colonel Markham and the officers of the 1st King’s Royal Rifle Corps the band of that regiment will attend. A verv attractive programme, which we shall publish later, is being drawn up.

HORRIBLE SUICIDE IN CAIRO. — A native woman who learnt recently that her husband was not faithful to her, resolved to commit suicide and for this end poured a quantity of petroleum on her clothes, and then applied a lighted match. Just as she had committed this insane act her husband appeared on the scenes and tried to save the woman, but the flames caught hold of his clothes. A cavass of the Greek consulate, who was passing at the time heard the shrieks of the poor couple and rushed in and did all that he could to save the two lives and the flames were finally extinguished. The woman, however, died almost immediately, but it is hoped that the man will recover from his serious burns.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
VISIT OF H.H. THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesterday was a great day in the annals of the Khedivial Yacht Club. At an early hour in the forenoon all the merchantmen in the harbour had dressed ship in honor of the occasion.

At about 3 p.m. the club began to present a very animated spectacle, as the members with their guests began to arrive. The club build- ing had been very tastefully decorated with flowers and plants and looked very charming.

Punctually at 4 p.m , as previously arranged, His Highness the Khedive with his suite arrived at the club. The Egyptian Army band played the Khedivial Hymn and the Khedivial standard was broken at the club’s mast. This was a signal for all the government ships and departmental buildings to dress with their bunting. His Highness was received at the Club steps by his Highness Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, Commodore of the Club, and Admiral Sir Maasie Blomfield K.C.M.G, RN. Vice-Commodore, and the members of the committee.
His Highness then proceeded to the reserved portion of the_verandah, whence he watched the races, taking a great interest in all the contests of the regatta.

The first event of interest apart from the event of the day, was the race between native sailing boats. These were all made fast to a rope by their sterns, with canvas stretched, and at a given signal all cast off and sailed away. The nine boats pre¬sented a very pretty sight, and his Highness the Khedive expressed great pleasure at the scene. Soon after this came the finish of the sailing race, for the challenge cup of his Highness the Khedive for which the entries were as follows :— Boat Time of Start Jessica \ 2.30 Akraba ) 2.32 Cattelaya 2.38 Tantah 2.40 Gumrook 2.43 Mssr 2.45 Calipso 2.56 Laurea

Prince Aziz’s magnificent cutter Laures first crossed the finishing line in fine style, with every stitch of canvas stretched, pre¬senting a fine spectacle which was greatly admired by the spectators watching from the club verandah. She was sailed for the Prince by Sagh. Phillips of the Coastguard Administration.

Then came the six-oared gig race, when, as usual, the gig of Prince Aziz came in an easy first, with the coastguard Harbour Depart- ment’s boat second, the Aida boat third, and coastguard training ship's gig fourth.

The last race was the final of the Rowing Club competition ; when the Canottieri easily best the German Sport Verein, drawing away from the start and gradually increasing their lead until they crossed the line six lengths ahead, although the Germans put on a very plucky spurt at the finish.

The Khedive then presented the prizes to the winners, each of whom he congratulated on his individual success. He then expressed to Prince Aziz and Admiral Blomfield the pleasure which his visit to the Club had afford- ed him, and wished it every success.

The Alexandria city police rendered great service in keeping the road clear, and the coastguards had formed a cordon entirely round the club, thereby ensuring the place being kept free from intruders.
The Egyptian Army band played during the afternoon. The detailed times, etc. of the vari- ous races will be published on Monday.

div.head: FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAYS. PURCHASED BY ANGLO-BELGIAN COMBINATION
div.p: The above company, which was constituted by Khedivial Decree in May, 1897, with a capital of LE. 200,000, has passed into new hands by the purchase by Messrs. Lambert and Ralli, on behalf of an Anglo Belgian group, of the interest possessed in the concern by the Witta Boctor family, and amounting to more than three-fourths of the total share capital. It is not yet known whether the local group represented by Mr. George Eid, whose option expired on the 20th Ultimo, will form part of the new combination. The new board will be entirely European, most probably half of the members will be English and the other half Belgian. Maltre Carton do Wiart, through whom the negotiations have been brought to a successful issue, will sit on the Board. It is intended to considerably increase the original capital, with the view of extending the present line of 164 kilo¬metres and introducing many improvements. The company also intends taking advantage of the falls in the town of Fayoum by uti- lising their motive power of 4,000 horse power for driving the machinery of the differ¬ent factories by electricity.

div.head: NEW BUILDINGS IN CAIRO.
div.p: The Societe Belge-Egyptienne de l'Esbekieh in conjunction-with the Daira Khassa have decided upon demolishing all the small tem¬- porary buildings now existing on the property purchased from the Djellal family some three years ago and situated behind Shepheard’s Hotel and in their place the company will erect nine immense blocks of residences similar in size to the one just completed at the corner of the Boulac road. The cost of these new buildings is estimated at £250,000 and it is expected that they will take between two and three years to construct. The foundations of the first are now finished and building operations will commence at once.

div.head: THE NEW TURBINE CUNARDER.
div.p: The new turbine propelled Cunard liner Carmania sails from Liverpool to New York on December 2, and her voyage is arousing considerable interest on both sides of the Atlantic. The passenger accommodation of the Carmania is in the same sumptuous style as that of the Caronia. By the addition of these two huge vessels, the Cunard Company has increased its tonnage during 1905 by 40,000 tons.

div.head: THE DIPHTHERIA EPIDEMIC.
div.p: Some of the local papers have stated lately that diphtheria is largely on the increase in Cairo, whilst our contemporary Le Phare d'Alexandrie contradicts the statement, and further avers that the Sanitary Department denies the existence of the disease. From enquiries made by our Cairo correspondent yesterday it seems that the number of daily cases is greatly exaggerated. From the returns issued by the statistical office we find that there were 11 new cases and 14 deaths reported during the week ending 30th September, and that the weekly average during the past four or five weeks does not exceed ten cases. Assuming the correctness of these records there is nothing to cause any alarm or to justify the statement that the disease exists in an epidemic form at present.

div.head: BANK OF EGYPT, LTD.
div.p: Mr. A. Zanneti Polzi has resigned his post as submanager, and the Board of Directors has appointed Mr. Vittorio G. Gallichi in his place. He is empowered to sign in conjunction with Messrs. Strong. Smith, or Jennings on behalf of the Bank of Egypt, Ltd., during the absence of the General Manager, Mr. A. Luzzatto.

div.head: THE BANK OF SALONICA.
div.p: The Cairo branch of the Bank of Salonica will be opened on Monday under the manage- ¬ment of Mr. Singer, formerly of the Credit Lyonnais. The offices are situated in the immeuble Mosseri, rue El Manakh.

div.head: SAN STEFANO CASINO.
div.p: The following is the programme of the Bra- cale orchestral concert to be given to-morrow morning at the Casino at 10 a.m. :- 1. Marelie-Nuptaile-Mendelssohn 2. Ouverture- La Sirene- Arber 3. Valse- La Charmeuse- Rene Maggier 4. Ballet-Sylvia- Delibes 5. Suite tire du ballet casse Neisette-Tsaichowsky Dause Russo- Arbe- Chinoise 6. Ouverture- Saul-Bazzini.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Khedivial express mail steamship El Kahira will leave Alexandria on Wednesday for Piraeus, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constanti¬nople.
The Ellerman S.S. Avon from Liverpool arrived yesterday with general cargo and passengers.
The Ellerman S.S. Sardinia sailed to-day from Liverpool for Gibraltar, Malta, and Alex¬andria:
The S.S. Egyptian Prince left Manchester on Friday with passengers and general cargo and is due to arrive at Alexandria via Tunis and Malta on or about the 27th inst.

div.head: RAISING OF THE PHARAON II.
div.p: During the last few days, great efforts have been made to get the salvage material for raising the Pharaon II into working order. It will be remembered by your readers that this large sucking dredger was sunk one night over five months ago, in the Dutch Basin owing to the carelessness of those who were responsible for the night watch ; and that, whilst bunkering sho quietly filled and sank. Subsequently the collision between the Congal and a Harrison boat occurred, which resulted, in the sinking of the former vessel, and which entailed many weeks of hard and difficult work, resulting in the successful refloating of the ship. All this, followed again by the general upset canned by the Chatham, greatly delayed the salvage operations on the sunken dredger, and to cause more worry, at the trials of the raising plant shortly before the Chatham caught fire, one of the doable lighters collapsed and had to undergo con¬siderable repairs and modifications.

However, all’s well that ends well, and the ffour pairs of lighters, each pair having a dis¬- placement of 250 tons, were yesterday placed in position, two-pairs on each side of the dredger (which by the way lay in 29 feet of water) and were all lashed with heavy chains to the cradle and each other, in such a manner that the air pipes, of which there were eight, protruded some few feet above the surface.

All being ready, soon after midnight, the pumping was started by several centrifugal and Grindl pumps under the supervision of M. Dormay, who has been in charge of this work since the day on which the Pharaon sunk. About seven o'clock this morning, the dredger and her four "attendants” suddenly rose more than two feet, and she has steadily continued to risen since ; till, at the time of writing she lies almost at her normal water line level. The salvage pumps of the Canal Company’s Progres were got to work on the water in her hold and engine room about noon, and she will go into the floating dock probably to-day.

Like the Congal, she now resembles nothing so much as a rock strewn coast after the tide has fallen ; festoons of yards of seaweeds hang from every point about her decks ; she is covered with slime and ooze, rusty, one mass of barnacles and dirt; a truly desolate and pitiable sight ; as for possibilities of future work with her I should fancy there are none. She is so covered with dirt and all manner of weeds that I would be surprised indeed it she can be made anything of, after her five and a half months’ submersion.

div.head: LOCUST SWARMS.
div.p: I informed you in my last letter the locusts were not expected to do ranch harm to the crops owing to the heavy rains which had fallen. Unhappily they are now more numerous than ever, and may yet do considerable harm. It is very difficult to persuade the natives to take any measures against them, for the Arabs of this district leave everything to Providence.

div.head: DEVOURED BY A CROCODILE.
div.p: While Bimbashi Nickerson, Inspector of the Mudirieh of Senaar was proceeding on a tour of inspection on the Dinder River one of his servants was carried away by a crocodile before the eyes of his comrades on the steamer. A sailor who witnessed the terrible sight, threw himself into the water and tried to save the wretched boy, but the reptile escaped with its prey. The generous Bimbashi on his return gave the mother of the boy a large sum of money. The sailor, who risked his life to save his friend will, I hear, be generously rewarded by the Government.

div.head: FEVER PREVALENT.
div.p: Miralai Dickenson Bey, Governor of the Blue Nile Province, has been rather seriously ill and great sympathy is felt for this energetic official, who has been taken to hospital at Khartoum. Fever has been very prevalent in the Southern Provinces. Mr. Marsden, Deputy inspector of Singa, who worked up to the last, was finally compelled to go on leave for three months.

div.head: MEDANI SCHOOLS.
div.p: The Government School built at Wad Medani will open very shortly. The masters are now on their way from Khartoum. The school will prepare pupils for the Gordon College and the funds for its maintenance are levied from the natives at the rate of five milliemes per ardeb, taken in the Uskur tax. Traders and well-to-do persons , will each have to pay L.E. 1 per annum for their sons’, education.
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.

div.head: OBITUARY. SIR HENRY IRVING.
div.p: John Henry Brodribb, who assumed the name of Henry Irving, was born on February 6,1838, at Keiton near Glastonbury, and educated at Dr. Pinches’ school, in George Yard, Lombard Street, London. He made his first public ap- pearance at the Sunderland Theatre, Sept 29, 1856, and after a series of engagements at Edinburgh, Glasgow, Manchester, and Liverpool, extending over nine years, he was engag- ed on July 30,1866, to play, with Miss Kate Terry, at Manchester, by Mr. Dion Boncicanlt, in an original play of his, entitled "Hunted Down.” This led to a London engagement, when he came out at the St. James’s Theatre as Doricourt in the "Belle’s Stratagem." He sub- sequently played at Drury Lane, the Hay- market, and the Gaiety theatres. In May, 1870, he transferred his services to the Vaudeville Theatre, playing Digby Grant in Mr. Albery’s comedy of the “Two Roses”, which character he sustained for 300 conse- cutive nights. His representation of “Hamlet” at the Lyceum Theatre (October 31, 1874) produced a great sensation among the play- going public, and opinion was at first much divided as to the merits of the performance, but it is now generally admitted that by his rendering of this and of other Shakespearian parts, Mr. Irving has placed himself at the head of English tragedians. "Hamlet” was played for 200 nights, the longest run of the play on record. He appeared in ''Macbeth’’ Sept. 18, 1875 ; in “Othello" in 1876 ; and next as Philip in Tennyson's drama of "Queen Mary” One of the parts in which he made his work and by which he will be best remem- bered by many, was that of Matthias in "The Bells” a powerful drama which had a long run at the time of its production, and has been fre- quently reproduced. Afterwards Mr. Irving played his Shakespearian parts in the provinces, in Scotland, and in Ireland. When in Dublin, he played "Hamlet" by the request af the Univer- sity, he having been presented with an address in the Dining Hall of Trinity College. In Jan., 1879, he added to his Shakespearian repertory by playing "Richard III." at the Lyceum. The withdrawal of Mrs. Bateman from the Lyceum gave Mr. Irving supreme control over the theatre, of which he had long been the mainstay. It opened under his management on Dec. 30, 1878, when he again played ''Hamlet" for 100 nights. The most remarkable incidents of Mr. Irving's manage- ment have been the production of “Othello" (in which he alternated the parts of the Moor and lago with Mr. Edwin Booth), "The Mer- chant of Venice," 'Much Ado about Nothing," The Cup," "Twelfth Night,” and "Faust," all which have been played in conjunction with Miss Ellen Terry. A public banquet was given to Mr. Irving at St James’s Hall, on July 4, 1883, shortly before his departure with the Lyceum company for a theatrical tour in the United States. A second visit to America was made in 1884, and before its close Mr. Irving delivered an address to the students of Harvard University on the art of acting. He also delivered an address by the invitation of the Vice Chancellor (Prof. Jowett) at Oxford, on June 26, 1886, On May 5, 1887, Mr. Irving was elected a life trustee of Shakespeare’s birthplace. On June 1 he produced Byron’s "Werner" at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of Dr. Westland Marston, with the fine result of giving over £800 to the distressed dramatist. On October 17 he visited Stratford- on-Avon for the purpose of making the dedica- tory speech at the presentation of a public fountain by Mr. G. W. Childs, of Philadelphia, and the next day left Liverpool for a third tour in America, lasting until March 24 1888. During his stay in the States he was given, on March 15, a reception by the American Geethe Society, and on March 19, by special desire :of the War Department, he took his company to the Military Academy at West Point where, with Miss Ellen Terry, he gave "The Merchant of Venice" in Elizabethan dress and without scenery of any kind. On March 12 the great blizzard occurred which paralysed New York for a week, and on that evening the Star, there Mr. Irving was performing, was the only theatre open. After a short season at the Lyceum he took "Faust” on tour, and at Bolton laid the foundation-stone of a new theatre. On Nov. 28 he was entertained at a publio banquet 5 in Birmingham. On'. Dec. 29 he produced ' Macbeth at tho Lyceum, with Miss EUeo v Terry as Lady Macbeth, andran it until the following surnmor, nearly 200 nights, which is the longest run of the play on record. In April of the year 1889 he visited Germany, where "Julius Caesar" and “The Merchant of Venice” were presented for him at the Berliner Theatre by Herr Barnay ; and on his return home he played, with Miss Ellen Terry, before the Queen at Sandringham. On Sept. 28 he revived at the Lyceum Watts-Philips’ play “The Dead Heart." The play ran the whole season, ending in the summer of 189-, after which, with Miss Ellen Terry, he made a short provincial tour, giving recitals of "Macbeth” with the accompaniment of Sir Arthur Sulli- van’s music. On Sept. 20, 1890, he produced “Ravenswood,'' by Herman Merivale, founded on Sir Walter Scott’s "Bride of Lammermoor." This was followed in 1891 by a revival of "Much Ado." "The Lyons Mail,”' and The Corsican Brothers.” During the season of 1892 Mr. Irving’s company played "Henry VIII.," a notable revival, at the Lyceum, the great actor taking the part of Cardinal Wolsey. His next part was not dissimilar to this, for he appeared as "Becket” in the late Lord Tenny son’s great play of that name. At the end of 1893 Mr. Irving gave numerous revivals of familiar pieces in his repertoire. He then took his company to America, and, on his return to the Lyceum in the spring of 1894, revived “Faust.” In September 1894, he appeared at Bristol in a little play by Dr. Conan Doyle, in which be figures as a Waterloo veteran. In 1899 he withdrew from the management of the Lyceum Theatre and has since made several tours in America, and also frequent visits to the provinces. He was knighted in 1895 and received the honorary degrees of LL.D. of Dublin, Cambridge and Glasgow Universities.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Vendredi 13 Octobre La situation monetaire nes’est pas ameliordes ioi plus qu’en Europe, oul’on parle d’aug- menter encore le taux d’escompte. Aussi les affaires sont-elles peu importantes sur notre marche, en depit d’une fermete relative: sur les fluctuations qui ont en lien depuis ven- dredi dernier deux tiers indiquent une hauses et un tiers une.baisse ; mais on peut dire d’une facon generale que le calme a prevalu sur toute la ligne, exoepte en National Bank, Agricole, Markets, Anglo-American Nile et Behera.

On espere une amelioration a la suite du versement de 10 £ par action que doit faire la Daira Sanieh lu-di prochain. Ce versement auquel les princes khediviaux avaient fait op- position vient d’etre autorise par, le juge de refere du Caire devant lequel le Gunvoroemant prptien avait porta Io differend. L- Somme considerable que ce paiement va mettre en circulation faciliters surement les operations de notre place.

Les Sucreries sont en pleine debandade a 30 francs. La direction du Caire a ferme les usines de Rodah, Magaga et Bibeh par raison d’eco- nomie, et M. Willcocks est en tonrnee d’ins- pection dans la-Hante-Egypte.
Une bonne operation a ete dernierement conclue par l’Egyptian Land and General trust a Alexandrie. II a’agit de l’achat des terrains Gourbal a des conditions avantageuses pour la Societe.

Le personnel venu d’Angleterre pour l’ex- ploitation des Oasis est arrive au Caire d’oh'il se rendra prochainement a ses divers portes de destination. Eu parlant des Oasis le directeur a dit que le sous-sol contenait des nappes d’eau inepuisables. II suffit de creuser les puita artesiens a des distances suffisantes les uns des autres pour maintenir la pression.

Un heureux envenement pour les porteurs d’Anglo American Nile e’est l’entente inter- venue entre cetta compagnie et la Ham- burg America pour le service fluvial a orga- niser en Egypte. Le cours de l’Anglo-American est monte de ce chef de 5 9/ a 5 15/16 et 6,et la tendance est toujours pour la hausse.

Un autre evenement de la semaine qui est digne de remarque e’est l’achat de la Fayoum Light Railways par un groupe de financiers anglo-belge qui se propose d’augmenter de beaucoup le capital initial (L.E. 200,000) en vue d’une extension considerable du reseau et d’autres amelierations. La Compagnie se pro- po¬se egalement d’utiliser les chutes d’eau de Fayoum dont la force atteint 4,000 chevaux vapeur comme force motrice des diverses usines de la localite.
La National Bank gagne 1/8 sur le cours de vendredi dernier et cioture a 27 5/16.
Il en est de meme de I’Agricole qui clotere a 9 3/4.

Le cours du Behera, qui avait flechi au com- mencement de la semaine, reprend vers la fin a 43, a la nonvelle de l’emission des 25,000 actions de l’Union Fonciere d’Egypte offertee aux por- teurs de Behera au prix de £5 et a raison d’une actions de l’Union Fonciere d’Egypte pour deux actions ordinaires de la Societe du Bedhera.
Les Markets a’avancent de 25/3 a 26 a cause naturellement de la prochaine reouverture des marches, ear l’etat des recettes ne justifie en rien cette hausse.
De 1/8 la Ramleh Railway monte a 7 3/16.
Les Dividendes Tramway monte egale- ment de 328 a 332, taudis’que les Priviledgies restent stationnaires a 162.
En Brasseries nous assistons au meme monvement: Les Privilegiecs a Alexandrie et au Caire restent sans changements, pendant que les Dividendes haussent respectivement de 10O a 105 et de 62 a 63.
En hausse encore la Salt and Soda de 33/6 a 34, l'Obligation Credit Foncier de 315 a 318 la Bauque d’Athenes de 135 a 135 1/4 et la Delta Light de 2 1/2 a 2 9/16.

Les valeurs qui au con^ ire ont faibli sont: la Delta Light de 13 1/16 a 12 15/16, l’Alex- andria Water de 15 /16 a 15, les Cotton Mills de 5/9 a 5/6, la Nungovich de 10 15/16 a 10 13/16 et la Land Bank de 9 7/8 a 9 3/4.
Les Estate, l’Investment et le Trust, si actifs naguere, restent sans transactions appreciables, queique soutenus aux cours respectifs de 1 7/32, 1 5/16 et 1 9/32, ainsi que l'Urbaine a 5 3/8.
Le prix de la Daira n'a pas sensiblement varie-e’est toujours 28, mais plutot acheteurs.
Somme toute, la semaine qui vient de se- couler n’a gu’ere ete plus active que les deux qui l’out precedee, mais les cours ont ete plus fermes .

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd’ hui midi et demie)
Comme un digne corollaire de la semaine, le marche a fait prevue sujourd' hui d’une inaction a peu pres complete. La corbeille a ete delals- see durant la plus grande partie de la matinee.
Aussi n’est il guere possible d’asrigner des variations aux cours des valeurs.
LA National Bank est toujours demandee a 27 5/16.
Mais l’Agricole flechit legerement a 9 3/4.
On achete la Behera a 43 1/8, soit au meme prix qu’hier.
L’Union Fonciere dont il est question dans notre chronique fait £ l ll/l6 de primp sur le prix d’emission. On l’achete a 6 11/16.
La Comptoir est stationnaire a 4 9/32.
Une reaction se produit sur la New Dairs don’t le cours flechit a 27 15/16.
La Ramleh Railway est au contraire plus ferme a 7 1/4.
Il ne serait guere possible d’assigner un prix aux Sucreries, car on n’a pas traite d’affaires ce matin. Tontefois, la valeur nous vient de Paris en reprise a 35 francs.
Le reste du marche est absolument calme of sans variations.

div.head: CYPRUS COTTON FIELDS.
div.p: The Colonial Office has published a report by Professor Wvndham Dunstan on the agri- cultural resources of Cyprus, with special reference to cotton cultivation, and with it correspondence on the subject which has passed between the Colonial Office, the High Com- missioner of Cyprus (Sir C. A. King-Harman) Professor Dunitan, and', the British Cotton- growing Association. Professor Dustan’s re- port is nearly eighteen months old, for he visited Cyprus in April, 1904, and his report was received at the Colonial Office in the following June. In recent years the produc- tion of ootton in Cyprus has not exceeded 1,000,0001b. per annum (of which aboot one half goes to Trieste add Marseillas), but for- merly the production was very much larger; during the Venetian oooupation the annual exports sometimes fose to 15,000,0001b., and Cyprus ootton was especially esteemed in Bogland. The industry is now in the hands of small proprietors and leaseholders, and as tbs rainfall is very variable the crop is liable to wide fluctuations. During the American Civil War, American “Orleans" seed was in- troduced and did well on irrigated land*, bat it has sinoe degenerated, and Bgyptian seed is generally considered unsuitable, thongh this o mchnion is probably not well foonded. The varieties now grown are two, known as "wet" and "dry" ootton, from the nataro of the soil in which they do best The yield is good, sometimes es much as 550lb. of lint being obtained per acre, and the average in a poor season not falling below 260lb. to 3001b. The ’,’4#” outton is not manured, bnt farm- yard manure is often applied to the "iret" ootton. Chemical fertilisers appear to be un- known. The "dry" ootton is harsh to the touch and short in staple, bnt of satia- fno wry oolour. It commands a lower prioe than irrigated ootton. “Wet", or irrigated ootton is usually of longer staple and of finer quality. This ootton obtains in Marseille/ and Trieste a rather batter price thau ordinary American “Upland," ranking next to the “JumeT' ootton of Bgypt; but in Manchester and Liverpool itU usually valued rather lower than American ’Upland,” bnt slightly above short-stapled Bast Indian ootton. “Dry” ootton is valaed at about one half penny a pound less than “wet” ootton. The cultivator considers 4d. to 5d. per lb. a remunerative price for ginned cotton. Professor Dunstan considers that- the three main obstacles to the revival of tho ootton- growing industry in Cyprus are tho absence of an effective system of irrigation, the want of an Agrioaltural Department, qualified and equipped to conduct systematic experiments with a view to the improvement of cotton oulture, and to supply information and advice to the native oultivator and the absence of shipping facilities—especially a direct servioe to Bogland with low freight rates. After a long correspondence/between Professor Dan- stan, Mr. Lyttelton, and 8ir C. A. King- Harman, the report was oommnnioated on April 8 to the British C.vton-growing Associa- tion, who ooncsrred in tho view that, exueri mentel work eBould be carried out with differente kinds of -reed?, sown at different seasons and in vsrfpus soils, in order to test the commercial possibilities of the industry.. Tho Asrociation.offered to contribute £iflOa year towards the expense of sneh work, if tbb Government wool 1 appoint a oimpeteqt agri cultural superintendent, with the necessary staff; and (her farther offered to oontribiio seed sod to look after the disposal of ai y ootton seot home. Mr. Lyttelton, however, decided that the Cyprns Goversnment ooold not.afford the expense whioh would, be in- volved in embarking on any large eolysme for the improvement of the indostry, and Use offer of the Association was therefore dr dined. This result is very disappointing, for Professor Danstan’* report iudiested that the prospects of snroeerfol cultivation with scientific methods uitable feed were distinctly good.

It has been a cardinal principle of Russian policy, says “Engineering," that the construc- tion of a Southern Asiatio railroad was by all poaajMe means to be prevented, and as snoh a system would have beefi fostered by railway development in Central and Sonthoru China these were ataq opposed. It was mainly through her lien on Persia that Roasia. proposed to. . render impossible direct and. continuous rail- way oonneotion between the Mediterranean and the Yellow Sea. Now that Russia cannot play, in Aaiatfo development, the part of the dog-in-the-manger, the Persian veto on the .outhem all-rad rente across the Continent may be held as subject to revision. International joalounea apart, the first link between Europe and snob a railroad woakl be the Ger- man line aero is Asia Minor, beginning on the Asiatio aide of tb) Bosphorus, and ending at ihe harbour pf El Koweit, on the Persian Golf —a total diatapoe of 1,750 miles. Bat the foot has been reoogniaed that the Power in posses- sion of this so called Bagdad Railway would command the interoommuqioation of three oontinenta ; and as the ambitions of- Ger- many cover so large a surface, it is_ in the last degree undesirable that thei key of the Asiatio railway system should ooma into German-hands. 'A Southern Asiatio railway system whioh- shOnld start within a sphere where Britiqji influenoe is seenre Is foand in Arabia; and it is proposed to oonneot the Mediterranean with the Eersian Galf by a line beginning at Alexandria, creasing the Isthmus of Snex to tk^ Galf of Akbah, end continuing thance to Bssorah and Koweit This line is fiOO miles /shorter than the German road, whioh starts .from the Asiatio side of the Bosphorus, bnt it would entirely lack the advantage poseeued by the German systsm of being a direot railway oommnnioetion with Earope. Betweeo El Koweit and the frontier of Beluohiatan, where British ioflusnoe is again auprepe, come* 700 mile* of Persian territory, which, it is assumed, oannot be muoh longer dosed .to railway . enterprise. There remains but 5)10^ mUea tol oonneot the the new system with the ^Indian railway at Kurrachw- Prom this latter point to the frontier of Bormah, the i'nter^l of 2,500 milee is already traversed; by railways, and a line tupplemantary to that system Is now in prooe*s of construction through British" Burmah. The torminns of this latter is on the Chinese frontier at Kanlong Ferry, bstweea whioh and Shing- hai there remains a diatanoo of 1,600 mile*. The ootaring of this by.the iron road is already in prooeea. Combping the various sections of the system thus outlined, we, adds "Engineering", get a totaf of 6,810 mile?, of which folly one-third has already been oonstrnoted, and of whioh some important links are in course of bring supplied.

div.head: MEDICAL INSPECTION OF SCHOOLS
div.p: Sir John Gurat continues to insist upon the curpiu tanum as a condition without which compulsory eduontion becomes a orael force ; and he is more oonvinoing on the point 'when spoaking, as a few nights, ago in the calmer atmosphere of Reading University College than when he is robbing shoulders with Socialist extremists. We heartily agree that the univer- sal medioal inspection of aohoolchildron in Germany is an example to be followed as soon as may be. Bnt it is important to be quite dear as to what should be the sequel to the disoovery by medioal inspector or teacher that a child is too nearly starved to learn or to remain in good condition. The official ioqniry will tell ns before long, no doobt, exactly how for voluntary ohar ty is meeting and can meet the case ; bat ought w6 to trust to, voluntary oharity alone t The S;Oialists’ short cat is the demand for the/ feeding, and oven the dothing, of the ohildron at the publio expense. Bnt the ratepayer will not and ought not to, take upon himself the paVant’a natural burden. The right prindplsis that accepted by S r John Gorst when he hints at powers for the looal authority to enforoi parental dntiei of this kind the psrant In ooeroion of the parent who wpn’t end temporary assistanoe to the parent who temporarily oan’t mast lie the final solution.

div.head: Notice.
div.p: The NILE COLD STORAGE Company, Limted, having found it necessary to increase the size of their shop premises, have now taken over the Shop and business known as the "English Butcher" situated at Nos. 148, 149, and 250 in the New Market, Cairo.

These premises will provide increased ac- commodation for the Company's numerous Clients, and for the more effective display of the goods imported by the Company, which are now well-known and appreciated in Cairo. The fresh stocks which are being imported for the approaching season will include MEAT, GAME, POULTRY, BUTTER, FISH, etc.

The Clients of the "ENGLISH BUTCHER" will also be able to obtain at the same address the class of goods which they have hitherto purchased there, and for which they may have a preference. In addition, they may, should they desire, make a choice of the imported goods of the Company, which are all of the finest quality.

The former proprietor of the "English But- cher" remains in charge of the shop, and notice is desired to be given that all accounts owing to him should be paid at the shop, or to the Nile Cold Storage Company. 26551-3A-2

div.head: Maple & Co.
div.p: The Largest, and Most Convenient Furnishing Establishment in the World HUNDREDS of THOUSANDS of POUNDS WORTH OF HIGH-CLASS FURNITURE, BEDSTEADS, BEDDING, CUTLERY, CHINA, GLASS, SILVER WARE, CARPETS, CURTAINS, BLINDS, &c., always ready for immediate shipment. A house furnished throughout in three days.

The “Cathcart ” Dining-Room Suite in Mahogany, Walnut or Fumed Oak, with brass mountings, consists of 6 ft Sideboard with handsomely carved pediment and panels, bevelled mirrors in back, lower portion usefully fitted with drawers, cupboards and cellarette; 3 ft 6 in Silver Cabinet, extreme height 7 ft fitted with clear glass shelves and mirrored back; 3 ft 6 in Dinner Wagon with two drawers and cupboard; Dining Table 4 ft wide and extending to 8 ft long, with extra leaves and patent screw; six very strong Dining Room Chairs with carved backs, upholstered in best marone morocco: Price includes packing and delivery F.O.B. London .. £70 0 0
Separate prices on application
“ONE of the SIGHTS of LONDON”

Maple & Co invite residents of Cairo, Alexandria, Damanhour, Tantah, Mansourah, Damietta, Samahud, Rosetta, Miniah, Ismailla, Port Said, and districts, when visiting London to walk through these spacious showrooms and galleries, and see for themselves all the latest novelties and new productions. MAPLE & CO also send patterns of all kinds of material, and illustrations of furniture, bedsteads, &c., on application, and give Inclusive f.o.b. estimates when desired.
TOTTENHAM COURT ROAD LONDON ENGLAND
